author: By Deb Amlen
title: Quite a Job, You Have to Admit
description: Sam Ezersky wishes us all a happy April Fools’ Day.
content: THURSDAY PUZZLE — It doesn’t happen every year, but once in a while the puzzle editors like to throw solvers a curveball on April 1. The most notable one — at least while I’ve been here — was in 2016, when Peter Gordon made a puzzle containing the message, “DUE TO BUDGET CUTS, THE NEW YORK TIMES CROSSWORD PUZZLE WILL END TOMORROW.” I thought that this was a hilarious April Fools’ joke that no one would possibly take seriously, so the Wordplay column for that day played along.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christina Caron
title: How to Start Healing During a Season of Grief
description: There is no singular way to respond to heartache or sorrow. Find the strategy that works best for you.
content: We are all grieving right now.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elisabetta Povoledo
title: Italy Bans Cruise Liners From Venice Lagoon, With a Catch
description: Though environmental groups praised the decision to detour big ships outside the fragile area, they are concerned about plans to temporarily dock them at Marghera, the lagoon’s industrial hub.
content: ROME — The coronavirus pandemic has kept most cruise ships docked. But the Italian government ruled this week that even when voyages resume, gigantic cruisers will no longer be permitted to pass Venice’s St. Mark’s Square and must find berthing outside its fragile lagoon.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Philip Galanes
title: Not Getting the Vaccine? Then You Won’t Be Seeing Your Grandkids.
description: A reader wonders what it will take to convince her mother to vaccinate herself against Covid-19.
content: My mom married a man 10 years ago and became a different person. She is still loving to us, but her politics changed drastically. Among other things, she is now adamantly opposed to vaccines. When my son was born a few years ago, it was a fight to have her get a flu shot before flying to visit us. Her husband refused and skipped our son’s bris. Now we’re arguing about the Covid vaccine. She wants to visit, but she and her husband refuse to take the vaccine. I told her until she does, she is not welcome to stay with us. She can’t believe I’m keeping her grandchildren from her. Where do I go from here? I want my kids to have more than a FaceTime relationship with her.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Bogel-Burroughs
title: Lawyers for George Floyd’s family say jurors should look past his drug use after hearing testimony about his addiction.
description: Many people who are addicted to drugs “are treated with dignity, respect and support, not brutality,” the lawyers said.
content: Two lawyers for the family of George Floyd said jurors in the trial of Derek Chauvin should look beyond Mr. Floyd’s drug use after his girlfriend testified on Thursday about their shared struggles with addiction.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By ‘Sway'
title: An Asian American Poet on Refusing to Take Up ‘Apologetic Space’
description: The writer and poet Cathy Park Hong discusses Asian outrage and why she’s seeking power, not assimilation.
content: This week, a Filipino woman was attacked in Midtown Manhattan during broad daylight. This assault came on the heels of the Atlanta-area shooting in which six women of Asian descent were killed and amid reports of rising crime against Asians. One group, Stop AAPI Hate, received nearly 3,800 accounts of incidents nationally between March 19, 2020, and Feb. 28.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Kenigsberg
title: ‘WeWork’ Review: The Sharing Economy or a Shared Delusion?
description: This documentary on the workspace start-up is a fast-paced, entertaining saga of relentless self-selling and a curious corporate culture.
content: Getting freelancers to split a workspace and convincing them that they’re part of an exclusive club is a neat trick, but it’s only the first flicker of gaslighting visible in “WeWork: Or the Making and Breaking of a $47 Billion Unicorn,” a documentary that suggests that WeWork — the tech start-up, or is it a real-estate start-up? — owed its growth less to the sharing economy than to shared delusion.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christopher Landau
title: The Real Reason for the Border Crisis
description: No one is holding American employers to account for their willingness to hire millions of unauthorized immigrants.
content: Once again, a humanitarian crisis is engulfing our southern border, as tens and potentially hundreds of thousands of migrants arrive from Mexico, Central America and around the world in the hope that the Biden administration will let them in and let them stay.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Beatrice Loayza
title: ‘Malni — Towards the Ocean, Towards the Shore’ Review: Embracing Our Ghosts
description: This ethereal experimental documentary by Sky Hopinka is an essential portrait of contemporary Indigenous life.
content: An essential portrait of contemporary Indigenous life that resists the touristic gaze, “Małni — Towards the Ocean, Towards the Shore,” the debut feature from the Ho-Chunk artist and filmmaker Sky Hopinka, isn’t too concerned with whether we fully understand the traditions and rituals it entrancingly commits to screen. It refreshingly centers the Native perspective, and beckons audiences onto its wavelength by tapping into something more intuitive, the stuff of dreams.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Wagner
title: The Yankees Start 2021 With Some Enthusiasm, and a Loss
description: Falling to Toronto in extra innings couldn’t dampen the spirits of a team buoyed by playing in front of a Yankee Stadium crowd for the first time in more than a year.
content: Twenty minutes before Gerrit Cole threw the first pitch of the 2021 Major League Baseball season on Thursday, his teammate, D.J. LeMahieu, emerged from the Yankees’ dugout and jogged to the outfield to stretch. He was met with something absent from Yankee Stadium since October 2019: applause and cheers from fans.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Giovanni Russonello
title: Biden Faces ‘a Very Precarious Point’ in the Coronavirus Response
description: With case counts rising, the president is in a complicated situation.
content: President Biden continues to receive high marks from the public for his handling of the coronavirus outbreak, and Americans are increasingly telling pollsters that they think the worst of the pandemic is behind us. On Thursday, the Consumer Confidence Index, a weekly measure of the public’s economic attitudes, hit its highest level since the start of the pandemic.
source.name: The New York Times

title: 5 Things to Do This Weekend
description: Our critics and writers have selected noteworthy cultural events to experience virtually.
content: The Jazz Standard closed its location on East 27th Street in December, becoming the first major New York club to permanently shutter amid the coronavirus pandemic. But its leadership insists that’s not the end of the story: Simmering tensions with the landlord were largely to blame, and the club is on the hunt for a new, post-Covid location.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natalie Diaz and Reginald Dwayne Betts
title: Poem: If I Should Come Upon Your House Lonely in the West Texas Desert
description: Natalie Diaz can be fiercely political, but, oh, my, can she also remind us to love.
content: These days, the sun lingers an hour longer. And with the coronavirus vaccines reaching more people every day, there is the hope that this pandemic is waning. And so I want to remember the love poem. The politics of holding someone close. I won’t pretend that the distance of these past months has reminded me of prison cells. But it has made me thankful for a little tenderness. Natalie Diaz can be fiercely political, but, oh, my, can she also remind us to love. As she says in “Grief Work,” the final poem of “Postcolonial Love Poem,” “Why not now go toward the things I love?” Selected by Reginald Dwayne Betts
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Glenn Thrush
title: A global aid program championed by Ivanka Trump has serious problems, a report finds.
description: So haphazard was management of the program that an independent watchdog was unable to determine whether it actually worked.
content: One of Ivanka Trump’s top initiatives — a legislative overhaul of programs assisting small businesses run by women around the world — was so haphazardly managed by a federal agency that an independent watchdog was unable to determine whether it actually worked.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Reem Kassis
title: Do You Have Nafas, the Elusive Gift That Makes Food Taste Better?
description: The Arabic word refers to a mysterious factor that renders some people’s cooking exceptional. Whether it’s innate or acquired is up for debate.
content: The chef Mohamad Orfali remembers how his grandmother, whom everyone called Fatoum, spent her days in her kitchen in the Syrian city of Aleppo when he was a child there. If she wasn’t preparing feasts, she was preserving the season’s bounty to stock her pantry — everything from tomatoes and eggplants to peppers, pomegranates and grape leaves. Her cooking was so exceptional, her dining table was never without guests hankering for a meal.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrés R. Martínez and Eileen Sullivan
title: Maine will open Covid-19 vaccination to anyone 16 or older on Wednesday. Virginia will do so on April 19.
description: The states join dozens of others, heeding a call from the president, to rapidly expand eligibility.
content: Maine announced on Thursday that adults 16 years and older will be eligible for a vaccine on Wednesday, more than a week sooner than the April 19 deadline the state previously set. Virginia also announced it would allow residents 16 or older to begin getting vaccinated against Covid-19 on April 19, joining more than 40 states that have sped up efforts to open the process to all adults as federal health officials warn about a possible fourth surge of the coronavirus.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Declan Walsh
title: ‘They Told Us Not to Resist’: Sexual Violence Pervades Ethiopia’s War
description: Rape is being used as a weapon as fighting rages in remote parts of Tigray region. “Even if we had shouted,” one woman said, “there was no one to listen.”
content: Mona Lisa lay on a hospital bed in Mekelle, the main city in war-torn northern Ethiopia, her body devastated but her defiance on display.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jesse Drucker
title: An Accidental Disclosure Exposes a $1 Billion Tax Fight With Bristol Myers
description: The I.R.S. believes the American drugmaker used an abusive offshore scheme to avoid federal taxes.
content: Almost nine years ago, Bristol Myers Squibb filed paperwork in Ireland to create a new offshore subsidiary. By moving Bristol Myers’s profits through the subsidiary, the American drugmaker could substantially reduce its U.S. tax bill.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matt Phillips and Mohammed Hadi
title: Wall Street Hits Another Record, Lifted by Tech Rally and Economic Optimism
description: Gains were largely driven by technology shares, and the record close was the latest in a series of new highs for the S&P 500.
content: A rally in big technology stocks, a tailwind of optimism from the Biden administration’s latest spending plan and a jump in oil prices combined on Thursday to lift Wall Street to another record, this one punctuated by the S&P 500 index’s close above 4,000 for the first time.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Your Thursday Briefing
description: ‘Rape culture’ in U.K. schools.
content: After weeks of harrowing anonymous accounts of sexual violence, sexism and misogyny at schools on a platform called Everyone’s Invited, local and national officials in Britain have begun investigations. On Wednesday, the government said an education body would conduct an immediate review of policies safeguarding students at both public and private schools.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ian Prasad Philbrick
title: Biden’s Afghanistan Dilemma
description: The deadline for the U.S. to leave Afghanistan is a month away. Here’s where things stand.
content: Is America’s longest war finally coming to an end?
source.name: The New York Times

title: ‘The 2021 Oscar Nominated Short Films’ Review: Major Issues in Brief
description: From social justice themes to stories about grief and reckoning with the past, this year’s nominated shorts get serious.
content: This year, the Oscar-nominated short films are being presented in three programs: live action, animation and documentary. Each program is reviewed below by a separate critic.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Johnny Diaz
title: Man Arrested in Road Rage Attack That Killed Mother of 6
description: The police said a “road rage encounter unknowingly developed” after a couple’s S.U.V. came close to another car during a merge from one highway lane to another.
content: A North Carolina man was arrested in a “road rage encounter” that killed a mother of six who was on an anniversary trip with her husband, the authorities said Thursday.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Cynthia Ozick Calls the New Philip Roth Biography a ‘Narrative Masterwork’
description: Blake Bailey’s comprehensive life of Roth features a parade of book after book, award after award, and lover after lover.
content: PHILIP ROTHThe BiographyBy Blake Bailey

description: Quotation of the Day for Thursday, April 1, 2021.
content: “I thought I would be so happy. And I just feel such grief because of the year of time I have lost and I will never get back.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael D. Shear, Emily Cochrane and Jim Tankersley
title: To Build Support for Plan, Biden Offers His Own Take on ‘Bipartisan’
description: President Biden’s $2 trillion infrastructure proposal is a test of his belief that he can generate popular backing across the country as Republicans seek to block him on Capitol Hill.
content: WASHINGTON — President Biden’s attempt to muscle through a $2 trillion plan to rebuild the country’s infrastructure — along with the tax increases to pay for it — will be a defining test of his belief that bipartisan support for his proposals can overwhelm traditional Republican objections in Congress.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Will Wright
title: Takeaways from Day Four of the Derek Chauvin trial.
description: Paramedics who responded to the scene said they did not see any signs of life in George Floyd. “In lay terms, I thought he was dead,” one said.
content: The trial of Derek Chauvin, the former police officer charged with killing George Floyd in Minneapolis, entered a new phase on Thursday with the testimony of paramedics who responded to the scene, making it the first time that jurors heard about Mr. Floyd’s medical condition in the immediate aftermath of the arrest.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Callie Holtermann
title: Would You Buy an NFT?
description: Would you want to own an official version of a digital good like a video, an image or a song? How much would you be willing to pay?
content: Do you know what a nonfungible token, or NFT, is? Shira Ovide explains in the On Tech newsletter “NFTs Are Neither Miracles nor Scams”:
source.name: The New York Times

description: How a small group of workers in Alabama are taking on one of the most powerful companies in the world.
content: Since its earliest days, Amazon has been anti-union, quashing any attempt by workers to organize.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Waldstein
title: ‘Here We Go Baby’: Francisco Lindor Truly Commits to the Mets
description: The superstar shortstop will stay in Queens through 2031 thanks to a 10-year, $341 million contract extension.
content: WASHINGTON — Unable to contain his jubilation, Francisco Lindor unleashed a short celebratory scream in his hotel room late Wednesday when his agent informed him that the Mets had agreed to give him a franchise record 10-year, $341 million contract extension.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Niraj Chokshi
title: United Airlines restarts pilot hiring as ticket sales rebound.
description: United will start by hiring the roughly 300 pilots who either had a conditional job offer last year or whose start dates had been canceled because of the pandemic.
content: United Airlines said it will start hiring pilots again, the latest sign that the travel industry is recovering from the pandemic.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Troy Closson
title: New York Will End Long-Term Solitary Confinement in Prisons and Jails
description: Isolation for more than 15 consecutive days will be barred in prisons and jails starting next March after years of efforts to restrict the practice.
content: In a far-reaching move that will fundamentally change life behind bars in New York, Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo on Wednesday signed into law a bill that will end the use of long-term solitary confinement in prisons and jails.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Philippe Sands
title: Britain Holds On to a Colony in Africa, With America’s Help
description: And together they are sabotaging their own efforts to curb China’s advances in the South China Sea.
content: President Biden, speaking at the State Department’s headquarters soon after his inauguration, called the “rule of law” one of America’s “most cherished democratic values.” The notion, a central part of his foreign policy and his faith in treaties and international institutions, is both a riposte to the Trump administration and a useful stick with which to beat China and Russia.
source.name: The New York Times

description: This week’s properties are in Williamsburg, TriBeCa and Concourse Village.

source.name: The New York Times

author: By David E. Sanger
title: 40 Years After Reagan, a Bet Big Government Can Get Something Done
description: President Biden feels a burning sense of competition, his aides say, to prove that democratic capitalism can work.
content: WASHINGTON — It has been 40 years since President Ronald Reagan declared in his first inaugural address that “government is not the solution to our problems, government is the problem.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anna North
title: What the History of Pandemics Can Teach Us About Resilience
description: Widespread disease outbreaks have the potential to shock societies into new ways of living.
content: This article is part of a series on resilience in troubled times — what we can learn about it from history and personal experiences.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matt Phillips
title: Investment Firm’s Collapse Put Unseen Risks on Full Display
description: Archegos Capital Management’s use of swaps helped conceal its exposure to huge blocks of shares but showed once again how lightly regulated derivatives can shake the financial system.
content: After the implosion of a little-known investment firm saddled banks around the world with billions of dollars in losses last week, one big question is being asked all over Wall Street: How did they let this happen?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jason Gutierrez and Mike Ives
title: In the Philippines, Attacks on Asian-Americans Threaten ‘Family’
description: The country’s foreign secretary responded forcefully to the recent assault on a Filipino immigrant in New York City. Some have called it hypocritical.
content: MANILA — When a Filipino immigrant was brutally attacked this week on a New York City sidewalk, the Philippine foreign secretary went on Twitter and advised his compatriots in the United States to fight back.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amanda Hess
title: Brandi Carlile Has Always Seen Herself Clearly. Now It’s Our Turn.
description: In her new memoir, “Broken Horses,” the singer-songwriter takes a deep look at how “a mean, scrappy little trailer girl with the wrong clothes” became a six-time Grammy winner.
content: Brandi Carlile was running late on account of a kitten emergency. She had arranged to pick up “this kitten thing” for her youngest daughter, Elijah’s, birthday, but then she was told she had to get it in the next 30 minutes, and the cat was an hour away. So now Carlile was sliding in front of her laptop screen for our interview with wet hair and a pink nose while also smoothly instructing an unseen collaborator in the details of deadline kitten extraction.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Keema Waterfield
title: The Lockdown Gave My Parents a Honeymoon Do-Over
description: No longer a willful preteen, she saw her stepfather in a new light: as a great fit for her mother.
content: This March, as the world marked one full year of the pandemic, my mother and stepfather celebrated their second go at a first wedding anniversary, 25 years after they divorced.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Serge Schmemann
title: The Freeing of the Ever Given
description: The stuck container ship became the butt of online jokes, but it was no minor crisis.
content: In the end, a full moon succeeded where puny machines could not, wrenching the mammoth barge out of the Egyptian mud in which it became wedged six days earlier. A spring tide finally set the Ever Given and its enormous stack of 18,300 shipping containers afloat again, drawing cheers from Egyptians on the shore and a virtual world beyond.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Noel Murray

content: Every month, streaming services in Australia add a new batch of movies and TV shows to its library. Here are our picks for April.

author: By Sarah Kliff and Margot Sanger-Katz
title: Billions in New Obamacare Subsidies Are Now Available on Healthcare.gov
description: Nearly everyone with a marketplace health plan can seek more financial help. Many uninsured Americans and people who buy their insurance elsewhere can also benefit.
content: Federal officials have reprogrammed Healthcare.gov, making new benefits available to tens of millions of Americans, weeks after Congress authorized spending billions on additional health law subsidies.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeannette Catsoulis
title: ‘Amundsen: The Greatest Expedition’ Review: Ice, Ice, Baby
description: This overstuffed trek through the chilly life of the famed Norwegian explorer Roald Amundsen is a handsome snooze.
content: The subject of the sluggish Norwegian biopic “Amundsen: The Greatest Expedition” might be the polar explorer Roald Amundsen, but its star is frozen water. On clothing and facial hair, from North Pole to South, ice whitens the screen. There’s every indication Amundsen’s heart is carved from it, too.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maya Goodfellow
title: Boris Johnson’s Government Is Built on Cruelty
description: Determined to make good on the nativist promise of Brexit, it has embraced anti-migrant authoritarianism.
content: LONDON — Last week, as Britain focused on its gradual emergence from lockdown, the home secretary, Priti Patel, laid out the government’s “New Plan for Immigration.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Annie Karni
title: Biden Administration Announces Ad Campaign to Combat Vaccine Hesitancy
description: The public awareness push includes 275 participating organizations that will speak to communities where skepticism of the coronavirus vaccine remains high.
content: WASHINGTON — The Biden administration on Thursday morning announced an ambitious advertising campaign intended to encourage as many Americans as possible to be vaccinated against the coronavirus.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Wilson Andrews
title: Why We Redesigned the Virus Trackers
description: Here’s what’s new on our coronavirus tracking pages.
content: In the coming days, we are rolling out major changes to the virus tracking pages that have been published multiple times a day for the past 13 months. These pages are a popular daily source of information for our readers, so we want to make sure everyone continues to find the information they need.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brett Anderson and Sergio Flores
title: A Crawfish Feast Where the South Meets Southeast Asia
description: Spring is turning into a comeback season at Crawfish & Noodles, a Houston restaurant famed for the Viet-Cajun style that has spread around the country.
content: HOUSTON — In early March, a delivery truck carrying dozens of bags of live Louisiana crawfish arrived at Crawfish & Noodles. The restaurant, in a district known as Asiatown, is arguably Houston’s best-known purveyor of Viet-Cajun crawfish. The style expands the flavor profile of traditional South Louisiana whole boiled crawfish, with modified spice blends and a twist developed by Vietnamese-American chefs: a generous bath in seasoned butter sauce.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Paul Krugman
title: Bidenomics Is as American as Apple Pie
description: Big spending on infrastructure goes back to the Erie Canal.
content: House Democrats are hoping to pass President Biden’s infrastructure bill by July 4, because of course they are. The Biden team is making a point of wrapping its economic initiatives firmly in the flag. First came the American Rescue Plan; now we have the American Jobs Plan paid for by the Made in America Tax Plan.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The New York Times
title: Are You Shopping for Obamacare? Tell Us About It.
description: We want to hear from people who enrolled for health insurance about their experiences signing up.
content: The stimulus bill that became law last month will spend billions to make health insurance more affordable. It will lower premiums for many who already buy their own coverage, and make millions newly eligible for financial help.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Glenn Kenny
title: ‘The Human Voice’ Review: Almodóvar Meets Cocteau Meets Swinton
description: The first English-language film from the Spanish director Pedro Almodóvar stars Tilda Swinton and adapts Jean Cocteau to sublime results.
content: A woman is brought to the end of her rope by a recalcitrant former lover. In what could be their last exchange, she speaks to the man over the phone. She cajoles, she feigns composure, she sneers, she renounces — things get kind of crazy.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amy Qin
title: BBC Correspondent Leaves China, Citing Growing Risks
description: John Sudworth left with his family after a propaganda campaign against him that followed coverage of the origins of Covid-19 and of a crackdown on Muslim minorities.
content: TAIPEI, Taiwan — A China correspondent for the BBC has left Beijing after coming under intense pressure and being threatened over the British public broadcaster’s coverage of subjects like the origins of Covid-19 and the government’s crackdown on Muslim minorities in the far western region of Xinjiang.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeannette Catsoulis
title: ‘The Unholy’ Review: ‘There’s Something About Mary’
description: Miraculous acts or evil deeds? This tame, trite horror movie has a familiar answer.
content: Satan is at it again in “The Unholy,” the first feature from Evan Spiliotopoulos and what feels like the millionth recurrence of a plot that turns an innocent young woman into the plaything of a soul-sucking demon.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Clay Risen
title: Bibian Mentel, Champion Paralympic Snowboarder, Dies at 48
description: After losing part of a leg to cancer, she dominated the sport for nearly two decades, winning three Paralympic gold medals.
content: Bibian Mentel, a champion Dutch snowboarder who lost her lower right leg to cancer, then returned to the sport a few months later and dominated it for the next 16 years, died on Monday at her home in Loosdrecht, the Netherlands. She was 48.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Coral Davenport
title: The Interior Department’s chief of staff shifts jobs after ignoring coronavirus guidance and planning an indoor party.
description: Jennifer Van der Heide will remain at the department as a senior counselor to Interior Secretary Deb Haaland.
content: The White House has directed the Interior Department’s chief of staff, Jennifer Van der Heide, to step away from her position after she tried to plan an indoor party with roughly 50 attendees to celebrate the confirmation of Interior Secretary Deb Haaland, according to an administration official with knowledge of the matter.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Reed Abelson
title: Doctors Accuse UnitedHealthcare of Stifling Competition
description: A multistate group of anesthesiologists filed cases in Texas and Colorado, accusing the insurance giant of squeezing them like a “boa constrictor.”
content: UnitedHealthcare, one of the nation’s largest health insurers, is being sued in two states by a large group of anesthesiologists who are accusing the company of stifling competition by forcing the doctors out of its network and by using its enormous clout to pressure hospitals and surgeons to stop referring patients to them.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elisabeth Egan
title: It Takes Gumption to Work on a Novel For 10 Years. Ask Angeline Boulley.
description: “Firekeeper’s Daughter” is a runaway success, but the years leading to its publication consisted of a long series of quiet mornings.
content: EARLY BIRD Wunderkind novelists are fun to hoot and holler about, but late bloomers deserve a solemn moment of silence. Let’s offer one up for Angeline Boulley, a 55-year-old mother of three, who toiled over "Firekeeper’s Daughter” for 10 years — during her son’s hockey practices and in work meetings; through seasons of celebration (including her kids’ high school and college graduations); and periods of tumult (a move from Sault Ste. author: By Sam Roberts
title: Michael Friedlander, Urban Architect of Offbeat Designs, Dies at 63
description: He was best known for the Spring Street Salt Shed, a crystalline structure that appears, with a little imagination, to form a coarse grain of salt.
content: In the 1970s, Michael Friedlander was an architecture student at the Cooper Union, his head bursting with bodacious, unconventional designs. Upon graduating, he settled for a stopgap job with the City of New York, which included more prosaic assignments like drafting blueprints to renovate locker rooms for sanitation workers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Billy Witz
title: North Carolina Coach Roy Williams Retires After 3 National Titles
description: Williams won three N.C.A.A. men’s tournament championships in 18 seasons with the Tar Heels. At North Carolina and Kansas, he reached the Final Four nine times.
content: Roy Williams, who restored the sheen to North Carolina basketball — and cut a sideline figure as a dapper dresser with a folksy charm — announced his retirement on Thursday, saying that he felt like he was no longer “the right man for the job.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Ross Sorkin, Jason Karaian, Michael J. de la Merced, Lauren Hirsch, Ephrat Livni and Sarah Kessler
title: Fact, or Corporate Fiction?
description: Companies still can’t resist April Fools’ Day.
content: Announcing phony news on April Fools’ Day is one of corporate America’s favorite occasions for shameless publicity stunts. But when stonks, Dogecoin and $69 million JPG files are real things that warrant serious business coverage, the risk of jokes being taken seriously could hardly be higher. Some say that’s a good reason to skip them, not to mention the gravity that a pandemic has cast over things.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Bogel-Burroughs
title: Officers should have stopped restraining George Floyd sooner, a former supervisor of Derek Chauvin’s testified.
description: Mr. Chauvin said the officers had to restrain Mr. Floyd because he would not stay in the back of a police car. “He was going crazy,” he said.
content: A sergeant who supervised Derek Chauvin testified on Thursday that Mr. Chauvin and other police officers should have stopped holding George Floyd down once he became unresponsive.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gal Beckerman
title: They Are Giving Hemingway Another Look, So You Can, Too
description: Lynn Novick and Ken Burns consider the seminal writer in all his complexity and controversy in their new PBS documentary series.
content: Could there be anything more subversive than turning a spotlight, in this moment, on Ernest Hemingway?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Niraj Chokshi
title: Frontier Airlines I.P.O. Signals a Travel Industry Recovery
description: The discount airline became the second to sell shares in a public offering this year as more people begin traveling again.
content: The pandemic is far from over, but some airlines believe the travel business is already on an upswing.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Desiree Ibekwe
title: His BBC Comedy Show Is Canceled. His Political Fight Continues.
description: Nish Kumar’s satirical late-night show “The Mash Report” ran for four years on the public broadcaster. Some believe it was a casualty of a “war on woke.”
content: LONDON — In the comedian Nish Kumar’s study hangs a poster of his face superimposed onto the famous “Guerrillero Heroico” photograph of Che Guevara, the communist revolutionary.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julie Bosman
title: Virus Surge in Michigan Is a ‘Gut Punch’ to Hopes of Pandemic’s End
description: The U.S. has entered a disconcerting phase: Vaccines are rolling out quickly, but upticks in cases raise the prospect of a new surge.
content: DETROIT — In a rural stretch of Michigan along the shore of Lake Huron, coronavirus outbreaks are ripping through churches, schools and restaurants where the virus has infected line cooks and waitresses. For more than a week, ambulances have taken several hourlong trips each day to rush severely ill coronavirus patients to hospitals in Detroit, Saginaw or Port Huron, where beds in intensive-care units await.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Daniel E. Slotnik
title: What Will Legal Cannabis Look Like in New York?
description: The state will become one of the largest markets of the drug in the nation. Here's what you can do now, and what will take some time.
content: [Want to get New York Today by email? Here’s the sign-up.]
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Megan Specia
title: Women Are Calling Out ‘Rape Culture’ in U.K. Schools
description: Thousands of anonymous online accounts have shined a spotlight on sexual violence against young women and girls.
content: LONDON — For weeks, the harrowing anonymous testimonies have poured in, one after another.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Perri Klass, M.D
title: How to Spot Depression in Young Children
description: We tend to think of childhood as a time of innocence and joy, but as many as 2 to 3 percent of children from ages 6 to 12 can have serious depression.
content: When parents bring their children in for medical care these days, there is no such thing as a casual, “Hey, how’s it going?” We doctors walk into every exam room prepared to hear a story of sadness and stress, or at the very least, of coping and keeping it together in this very hard year, full of isolation, loss, tragedy and hardship, with routines disrupted and comfort hard to come by.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Marie Fazio
title: It’s Easy (and Legal) to Bet on Sports. Do Young Adults Know the Risks?
description: Americans wagered $13 billion on sports in 2019. With sports betting now legal in nearly half the states, experts fear the addiction danger is not being adequately addressed.
content: Saul Malek grew up surrounded by sports.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Dooley and Hisako Ueno
title: Japan Is Finding It Harder to Stay Quiet on China’s Abuse of Uyghurs
description: Public awareness of the issue is growing in the country, spurred in part by the work of Uyghur activists, and that is increasing pressure on the government to take action.
content: TOKYO — Last summer, Halmat Rozi, a Uyghur Muslim living in Japan, received a video call from his brother in China’s western Xinjiang region. His brother said he had someone he wanted Mr. Rozi to meet: a Chinese security officer.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katie Rogers
title: Jill Biden, in California, Lends Support to Farmworkers Seeking Vaccinations
description: The first lady was in Delano, Calif., to mark the birthday of César Chávez, the labor organizer who formed the country’s first successful farmworkers’ union.
content: DELANO, Calif. — Jill Biden, the first lady, traveled to California on Wednesday to visit a pop-up vaccination site for farmworkers who have lobbied for priority access to shots during the pandemic.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Kolomatsky
title: The Brooklyn-Manhattan Rent Gap Is Shrinking Fast
description: During the pandemic, the difference between the median rent in the two boroughs nearly vanished.
content: Twenty or 30 years ago, you went to Brooklyn because you couldn’t afford Manhattan rents. By the early 2000s, the borough began catching up with its more expensive neighbor. A new generation of residents was moving in, a sports arena was in the works and lots of new development was rising — along with rents.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gillian R. Brassil, Kevin Draper and Gwen Knapp
title: Tiger Woods Update: Sheriff Says Crash Investigation Is Done
description: Alex Villanueva, the sheriff of Los Angeles County, said that the authorities would need Woods’s permission to release the results of the investigation.
content: The investigation into Tiger Woods’s single-vehicle crash in February is finished, but the results cannot be released publicly until Woods gives permission, the Los Angeles County sheriff said in a Facebook Livestream on Wednesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Joshua Barone
title: With Open Ears, Indian Ragas and Western Melodies Merge
description: Amit Chaudhuri charts his musical journey in a new book, “Finding the Raga: An Improvisation on Indian Music.”
content: Amit Chaudhuri, an author and vocalist, blends memoir and music appreciation in “Finding the Raga: An Improvisation on Indian Music,” out now from New York Review Books. In it, Chaudhuri charts a personal journey that began with a Western-oriented love for the singer-songwriter tradition, followed by a headlong immersion into Indian classical music.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kristen Yoonsoo Kim
title: ‘Every Breath You Take’ Review: The Therapist as Trauma Victim
description: Casey Affleck plays a vaunted psychiatrist whose life and career are derailed after he boasts about a miraculous new technique, which then fails tragically.
content: With chillingly minimal interiors, ominously crescendoing music, and a bluish-gray palette, “Every Breath You Take” announces itself as a thriller in predictable ways. Directed by Vaughn Stein and written by David K. Murray, the movie coasts on so many tropes that you almost expect it to subvert them, but the plot remains equally foreseeable.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Concepción de León
title: What You Need to Know About Your Vaccine Card
description: For now, the best way to show that you’ve been inoculated against the coronavirus is a simple white card. Here, your key questions answered.
content: As vaccinations become more widely available for people in the United States and travel starts picking up, many people have started sharing their simple white vaccination cards on social media as prized new possessions.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mark Miller
title: Turning Away From Nursing Homes, to What?
description: Covid-19 has driven down Americans’ demand for senior care facilities. Building support for more elders to remain at home requires systemic changes.
content: Regina Smith has dedicated her career to keeping seniors out of nursing homes. A geriatric social worker at an adult day care network in Indianapolis, she strives to provide services that can help people live independently.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Glenn Kenny
title: ‘Concrete Cowboy’ Review: Acquiring Horse Sense on the Philly Streets
description: Idris Elba leads us through the long-buried heritage of America’s Black cowboys, manifested in their modern-day urban descendants.
content: There’s a quote that’s been circulating for years and years, apocryphally attributed to Ronald Reagan, Winston Churchill and a few other white men: “There is nothing so good for the inside of a man than the outside of a horse.” In “Concrete Cowboy,” the improving aspects of horseback riding — and, yes, stable maintenance — are demonstrated in the tale of a troubled Black teenager, Cole (Caleb McLaughlin).
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katharine Q. Seelye
title: Daniel Laske, a ‘Social Justice Warrior,’ Dies at 21
description: He wanted to combine his passions for medicine and politics to make the world a better place. Then he tested positive for the coronavirus.
content: This obituary is part of a series about people who have died in the coronavirus pandemic. Read about others here.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Futterman
title: In Tennis, Tough Decisions as Players Adjust to Shrunken Paydays
description: With less money to be won, many players are working harder than ever, especially those not lucky enough to have million-dollar endorsement portfolios.
content: Lloyd Harris has been on a bit of a roll this year.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrés R. Martínez
title: A decline in testing may be masking the spread of the virus in some states.
description: Efforts to speed up vaccinations have diverted resources from testing, and fewer people seem to seek out a test unless they are ill.
content: Declines in coronavirus testing in many states in the South and the Great Plains are making it harder to know just how widely the virus may be spreading in those states, even as restrictions are lifted and residents ease back into daily life, experts say.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Roberts
title: Paul Feinman, First Openly Gay Judge on N.Y. High Court, Dies at 61
description: “I hope I add to the diversity of perspectives that the court considers,” he said before being unanimously confirmed to the Court of Appeals in 2017.
content: Judge Paul G. Feinman, the first openly gay jurist to serve on New York State’s highest court, the Court of Appeals, died on Wednesday at a Manhattan hospital. He was 61.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: Film Club: ‘Inside the Battle Over George Floyd Square’
description: After almost a year of protests, the trial of the former officer accused of killing Floyd has begun. What does the debate over a memorial site tell us about the struggle for racial justice in one city, and for America?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stanley Reed
title: OPEC and Its Allies Agree toGradual Increases in Oil Production
description: Some members wanted to take advantage of what they saw as a growing global thirst for oil as economies slowly expand after pandemic lockdowns.
content: OPEC and its allies, including Russia, announced on Thursday they would gradually increase oil production over the next three months.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Eligon, Shaila Dewan, Tim Arango and Nicholas Bogel-Burroughs
title: Clerk Who Questioned $20 Bill Watched Floyd Arrest With ‘Disbelief and Guilt’
description: During the third day of Derek Chauvin’s trial, witness after witness agonized over whether they could have done anything to stop what would eventually happen to George Floyd.
content: MINNEAPOLIS — He chatted with a store clerk about playing football. He grabbed a banana off a shelf, flipped through a wad of cash, and hugged and exchanged pleasantries with a woman, laughing with his hand on her back.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Roberta Smith
title: It’s Time to Put Alice Neel in Her Rightful Place in the Pantheon
description: A large retrospective feels at home in the Metropolitan Museum of Art’s grandest galleries and should silence any doubt about the artist’s originality or her importance.
content: It is said that the future is female, and one can only hope. But it is important to remember that the past, through continuous excavation, is becoming more female all the time. The latest evidence is the gloriously relentless retrospective of Alice Neel (1900-1984), the radical realist painter of all things human, at the Metropolitan Museum of Art.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard C. Paddock
title: Myanmar Soldiers, Aiming to Silence Protests, Target Journalists
description: The security forces have arrested at least 56 reporters, outlawed online news outlets and crippled communications. Young people have stepped in with their phones to help document the brutality.
content: Ten days after seizing power in Myanmar, the generals issued their first command to journalists: Stop using the words “coup,” “regime” and “junta” to describe the military’s takeover of the government. Few reporters heeded the Orwellian directive, and the junta embraced a new goal — crushing all free expression.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ezra Klein
title: Are We Much Too Timid in the Way We Fight Covid-19?
description: The debate among doctors, epidemiologists and economists is still going strong.
content: Here’s a question I’ve been mulling in recent months: Is Alex Tabarrok right? Are people dying because our coronavirus response is far too conservative?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vanessa Friedman
title: Enter the Age of the Vaccine Selfie
description: From topless politicians to designers, it’s a thing. And it’s part of a longer tradition than you might expect.
content: Someday, when the history of the pandemic is written, it may be a narrative told partly in images: the despair of crowded hospitals and body bags, the fear and isolation of the masks. And then the balm of a smiling individual, one sleeve rolled up practically to the collarbone, with a medical worker poised to jab a needle into their upper arm. Log in to any social platform, and the picture — not to mention The Pose — is almost impossible to miss.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stephanie Saul
title: For many college students, pandemic life is disappointing. For others, it is a financial crisis.
description: As campuses struggle under the shadow of the pandemic, many students report having trouble paying for food, housing and other basic needs.
content: Colleges around the country have been struggling under the shadow of the coronavirus, facing declining enrollment and major budget cuts. And students have mourned the loss of the traditional college experience, grappling with the disruption as campuses closed and many classes moved on line.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Waldstein
title: Mets-Nationals game is postponed after positive tests.
description: Francisco Lindor’s Mets debut will have to wait after Washington had at least three positive coronavirus tests among its players, and several other players who had been in close contact.
content: WASHINGTON — Major League Baseball sailed through roughly six weeks of spring training without any major coronavirus disruptions, but just hours before first pitches were set to be thrown across the country, the problem lurched up again.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Apoorva Mandavilli
title: Can Vaccinated People Spread the Virus? We Don’t Know, Scientists Say.
description: Researchers pushed back after the C.D.C. director asserted that vaccinated people “do not carry the virus.”
content: The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention on Thursday walked back controversial comments made by its director, Dr. Rochelle P. Walensky, suggesting that people who are vaccinated against the coronavirus never become infected or transmit the virus to others.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Wolfe
title: Coronavirus Briefing: What Happened Today
description: Two states, Maryland and Michigan, offer microcosms of the issues facing the U.S.
content: The United States is in a perilous race between vaccinating residents as quickly as possible and succumbing to a new wave of infections driven by the faster-spreading variants.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melina Delkic
title: Your Friday Briefing
description: Threats to pandemic progress everywhere.
content: Experts around the world are reminding people that despite hope from Covid-19 vaccinations and a clearer path forward, it is much too soon to let down our guard.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Goodwillie
title: A Novel of the City, Alive to Its Hidden Connections
description: In “Ghosts of New York,” Jim Lewis introduces four characters and follows their intersecting paths.
content: GHOSTS OF NEW YORKBy Jim Lewis
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melissa Eddy
title: Merkel’s Latest Pandemic Challenge: Leading as a Lame Duck
description: The German chancellor, known for her cool, solution-oriented response in the pandemic’s early stages, faces her greatest challenge yet as cases rise and patience plummets months before her final term ends.
content: BERLIN — What a difference a year makes.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Margaret Lyons
title: How Much Watching Time Do You Have This Weekend?
description: Our TV critic recommends a sweet Japanese series of animated shorts, a warped new comedy about tech overreach and a 13-season classic.
content: Every Monday and Friday, Margaret offers hyper-specific viewing recommendations in our Watching newsletter. Read her latest picks below, and sign up for the Watching newsletter here.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Annie Correal
title: How N.Y.C.’s Population Expert Says the City Will Bounce Back
description: Joseph J. Salvo, who is retiring after nearly 30 years as New York City’s chief demographer, is optimistic about New York City’s recovery after the pandemic.
content: In nearly three decades as New York City’s chief demographer at the Department of City Planning, Joseph J. Salvo has been the top expert on the city’s population, providing data and analysis of the city’s always-changing populace to help city officials, community organizers and journalists understand the most diverse city in the world.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neil Vigdor
title: A Man Found 15,000 Bees in His Car After Grocery Shopping
description: An off-duty firefighter in Las Cruces, N.M., whose hobby is beekeeping, safely removed the swarm from the man’s car in an Albertsons supermarket parking lot.
content: He had just finished grocery shopping, but a New Mexico man got much more than he bargained for when he returned to his car in the store’s parking lot: A swarm of 15,000 honey bees had taken over the back seat.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jacey Fortin
title: Man Is Charged With Smuggling in Crash That Killed 13 Migrants in California
description: More than two dozen people were crowded into an S.U.V. that collided with a tractor-trailer near the border. Jose Cruz Noguez was accused of coordinating the smuggling attempt.
content: Federal authorities in California charged a man on Tuesday with coordinating a smuggling attempt that resulted in the deaths of 13 Mexican and Guatemalan citizens in one of the deadliest border-related crashes in decades.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: What Students Are Saying About Returning to Normalcy, Having Open-Minded Discussions and Representation in Acting
description: Teenage comments in response to our recent writing prompts, and an invitation to join the ongoing conversation.
content: Welcome to another roundup of student comments on our writing prompts. This week we asked students if they are nervous about returning to normal life after the pandemic; how they handle themselves in discussions with those who hold differing views; and how closely actors’ identities should reflect the roles they are hired to play.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alisha Haridasani Gupta
title: Child Care in Crisis: Can Biden’s Plan Save It?
description: Child-care centers improvised during the pandemic, scrambling to stay open with razor-thin budgets and little government guidance. How long will the short-term solutions last?
content: In suburban Ohio, a decades-old child-care center that was thriving before the pandemic shut its doors for the final time in August.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Brooks
title: How Covid Can Change Your Personality
description: Distancing and isolation shaped who we are.
content: I don’t know about you, but I’ve found the latest stage of the pandemic hard in its own distinct way. The cumulative effect of a year of repetition, isolation and stress has induced a lassitude — a settling into the familiar, with feelings of vulnerability. The shock of a year ago has been replaced by a sluggish just-getting-to-the-end.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Thomas Kaplan
title: Ray LaHood, Obama’s transportation secretary, failed to disclose a $50,000 check from an associate of a Lebanese-Nigerian billionaire.
description: Mr. LaHood did not disclose the check on two government ethics forms, federal prosecutors said.
content: Ray LaHood, who served as transportation secretary for President Barack Obama from 2009 to 2013, took $50,000 from an associate of a Lebanese-Nigerian billionaire in 2012 and failed to disclose it, federal prosecutors announced Wednesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matt Wolf
title: Setting the Stage Once Again for Shakespeare, and Live Theater
description: With coronavirus restrictions easing in England, several venues have plans to give classic plays new life.
content: LONDON — Shakespeare is coming back, and I can’t be the only person who has missed him.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: April Fools’
description: What story or memory does this day inspire for you?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Benedict Carey
title: Science Plays the Long Game. But People Have Mental Health Issues Now.
description: I’ve reported on behavior and mental health for 20 years. As I exit, I can’t help but wonder why researchers have placed so little emphasis on helping people in distress today.
content: When I joined the Science staff in 2004, reporters in the department had a saying, a reassuring mantra of sorts: “People will always come to the science section, if only to read about progress.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Wines
title: Texas lawmakers advance a bill that would make voting more difficult, drawing comparisons to Georgia.
description: The Texas measure comes on the heels of efforts in Iowa and Georgia, where lawmakers significantly tightened voting rules last month.
content: Lawmakers in Texas, a state that already claims the most onerous voting laws in the nation, on Thursday took a major step toward making it even tougher to cast a ballot, the latest in a bevy of Republican-backed efforts to restrict voting ahead of the 2022 midterm elections.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nick Czap
title: It Looks Like a Vespa, Rides Like a Vespa, but Doesn’t Smell Like a Vespa
description: An Irish mechanic in London has developed a kit to transform classic Italian scooters into clean-riding electric machines.
content: Among the iconic designs of Italy’s vibrant postwar period, few capture the essence of La Dolce Vita like Vespas and Lambrettas, the free-spirited motor scooters that brought mobility to the masses and became beloved across Italy, and subsequently, the world.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeremy Engle
title: Lesson of the Day: ‘Rich Countries Signed Away a Chance to Vaccinate the World’
description: In this his lesson, students will learn about the stark inequalities in vaccine access across the globe, then consider what the United States should do to close the gap.
content: Featured Article: “Rich Countries Signed Away a Chance to Vaccinate the World” (PDF excerpt) by Selam Gebrekidan and Matt Apuzzo (You can read the full article here, but because it is quite long, our Questions for Writing and Discussion deal only with the information in the excerpt.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Marie Fazio and Tim Arango
title: What we know about Courteney Ross, George Floyd’s former girlfriend.
description: Ms. Ross was called on by the prosecution to testify on Thursday.
content: Courteney Ross, a former girlfriend of George Floyd, was called on by the prosecution to testify on Thursday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Benjamin Hoffman
title: Twelve hours of baseball await.
description: Of four games being broadcast nationally on ESPN, the most interesting will probably be the Astros’ road opener at Oakland.
content: The expected highlights of opening day, which will stretch from 1:05 p.m. Eastern time until approximately 1 a.m., include the Hall of Famer Tony La Russa’s return to managing with the Chicago White Sox, Francisco Lindor’s debut with the Mets and the Los Angeles Dodgers beginning their title defense.But the most interesting game of the day is quite likely the Houston Astros’ road opener at Oakland, where they will face a hostile regular season crowd for the first time since their elaborate sign-stealing scheme (which helped the team win the 2017 World Series) was revealed. That game between the Astros and the Athletics is one of three opening day games that will be broadcast nationally on ESPN (the Mets-Nationals game, which was also set for ESPN, has been postponed). Here is the full opening day schedule.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By A.O. Scott
title: ‘Malmkrog’ Review: Now You’re Talking
description: Welcome to a three-hour, multilingual 19th-century house party, organized by the Romanian filmmaker Cristi Puiu.
content: It’s winter, sometime in the late 19th century, somewhere in Russia or Eastern Europe. A small group has gathered at a country estate to discourse — over Champagne, tea, brandy, lunch and dinner, supplied by a squadron of silent maids and waiters — about matters of the utmost seriousness. How can we distinguish good from evil? Is killing ever justified? What is the future of Europe?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Gelles
title: Delta and Coca-Cola face backlash from Republicans after opposing Georgia voting law.
description: Hours after the companies made their statements, Georgia’s governor took aim at the chief executive of Delta. And Republicans in the Georgia state legislature floated the idea of increasing taxes on Delta as retribution.
content: For two weeks, Delta Air Lines and Coca-Cola had been under pressure from activists and Black executives who wanted the companies to publicly oppose a new law in Georgia that makes it harder for people to vote. On Wednesday, six days after the law was passed, both companies stated their “crystal clear” opposition to it.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Spencer Bokat-Lindell
title: Can New York’s Marijuana Legalization Light Up a New Path?
description: Yes, it’s welcome news for cannabis connoisseurs. But for many advocates, the focus is on making amends for the war on drugs.
content: This article is part of the Debatable newsletter. You can sign up here to receive it on Tuesdays and Thursdays.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sheri Fink
title: ‘It Takes Time’: I.C.U. Workers Help Their Former Covid Patients Mend
description: They survived serious cases of Covid-19, sometimes spending weeks on a ventilator, but not without complications. Now, a special clinic at an L.A. hospital is helping them get back to their lives.
content: LOS ANGELES — Three days after being released from Martin Luther King Jr. Community Hospital, Gilbert Torres returned on a stretcher, a clear tube snaking from his nose to an oxygen tank. It was the last place he wanted to be.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Judge John Hodgman on Running Out of Underwear
description: A married couple’s contention over a broken washer.
content: Kate writes: We were without a washer for a few weeks. Rather than buy new underwear, my husband, Steve, pulled out a pair of scissors and invented “short johns.” You take a pair of long johns, snip them off midthigh and then wear them like normal underpants. I say he’s ruining perfectly good clothing. But he still happily sings “short johns, short johns!” whenever he puts them on. I worry he’ll strike again.
source.name: The New York Times

title: The T List: Five Things We Recommend This Week
description: An augmented reality app, Maggie Lee’s latest installation — and more.
content: Welcome to the T List, a newsletter from the editors of T Magazine. Each week, we share things we’re eating, wearing, listening to or coveting now. Sign up here to find us in your inbox every Wednesday. And you can always reach us at tlist@nytimes.com.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tyler Kepner
title: Baseball and Its Fans Are Back. Just Not Way, Way Back.
description: The crowds were still limited because of the coronavirus, but opening day of 2021 looked very different from the stark scenes at parks last summer.
content: They opened the gates at last on Thursday, six months after the end of a brief and surreal regular season played before no fans. Opening day for 2021 brought none of the usual standing-room-only crowds; with limited capacities, the games looked more like sleepy gatherings in mid-April. But the buzz was authentic, and there’s nothing like the real thing.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ruth La Ferla
title: Laura Wasser, She Who Will Cleave the Union of Kim and Kanye
description: A Hollywood divorce lawyer with lots of practice.
content: Among Laura Wasser’s singular gifts is her talent for spinning a tale. One of Hollywood’s premier divorce lawyers, she has cataloged her clients’ foibles, anxieties and misapprehensions in a book and on her social media platforms. There was the wife of a Hollywood producer who imagined that she would still be entitled, post-split, to fly on the movie studio’s private jet. Not a chance, Ms. Wasser told her crisply. “You are no longer Mrs. Producer.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Veronica Penney
title: If You Build It, They Will Bike: Pop-Up Lanes Increased Cycling During Pandemic
description: A study of European cities adds to a growing body of evidence that investments in cycling infrastructure can encourage bike commuting, which helps cut greenhouse gas emissions.
content: Adding bike lanes to urban streets can increase the number of cyclists across an entire city, not just on the streets with new bike lanes, according to a new study. The finding adds to a growing body of research indicating that investments in cycling infrastructure can encourage more people to commute by bike, which helps reduce greenhouse gas emissions and improve health.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Bogel-Burroughs
title: George Floyd’s girlfriend described their relationship: A shared struggle with addiction, their first kiss, a ‘dad selfie.’
description: Courteney Ross, 45, said she and Mr. Floyd had started taking opioids when they were prescribed for chronic pain.
content: Courteney Ross, who was dating George Floyd for nearly three years before his death in May, delivered tearful testimony on Thursday about their shared struggle with an opioid addiction.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jill P. Capuzzo and Claudia Gryvatz Copquin
title: Homes for Sale in New York and New Jersey
description: This week’s properties are a five-bedroom house in Bellmore, N.Y., and a four-bedroom house in Watchung, N.J.
content: Click on the slide show to see this week’s featured properties:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Liam Stack
title: The Push to Vaccinate 20,000 Holocaust Survivors in New York
description: One survivor who got her vaccine, Eva Rose, 96, said the last year has been “lousy,” but added: “I am still here, thank God.”
content: A year spent hiding at home from the coronavirus has given Anne Bertolino, 96, a lot of time to dwell on the past: the anti-Semitic abuse she suffered on the streets of Hamburg as a child; the grandparents who pushed for her and her sister to leave the country for their own safety; and her mother, a widow who was killed in Auschwitz.

author: By Melissa Febos

author: By Marcus J. Moore
title: Esperanza Spalding’s Quest to Find Healing in Music
description: The bassist, vocalist and producer’s latest project is a therapeutic suite of songs sparked at an artists’ retreat she started during the pandemic.
content: Esperanza Spalding has never been one to sit idle. Her wandering spirit has brought this 36-year-old musician major achievements over the past decade and pushed her work in new directions. In 2017, Spalding, a bassist, vocalist and producer, spent 77 straight hours in the studio, writing and arranging songs. The resulting album, “Exposure,” was pressed directly to CD and vinyl for a limited release of just 7,777 copies. Her next project, “12 Little Spells,” explored the healing power of music; each song correlated with a different body part.

title: 11 New Books We Recommend This Week

content: A couple of smart writers recently have put words to something that seems self-evident but bears keeping in mind for anybody who loves to read: “Literature is made of culture,” the critic Laura Miller wrote at Slate, while on Twitter the novelist Sheila Heti wrote, “Writers are their times.” (Or something to that effect, anyway: Heti, a dedicated self-deleter, removed her tweet not long after posting it.) The point is that books don’t exist in a vacuum, and even works of pure history or fantasy are shaped by the context of the writer’s own world.

content: An article on Monday about the revival of hunting and trapping certain predators in Montana misstated how Gov. Greg Gianforte of Montana characterized his trapping experience. He said he had been trapping since he was a “tot,” not that he had been trapping wolves since that time. Because of editing errors, the article also described incorrectly the state and one of its senators.
